text: Hey, what's up creators? My name is Luke
and welcome back to the first hour of
Unreal Engine course. In today's video,
we're going to be launching Unreal
Engine, showing you how we can make our
very first Unreal Engine project, and
then also walking you around the Unreal
Engine user interface, laying the
foundation for the course to come. That
being said, let's jump straight into
opening Unreal Engine. You probably
already have the Unreal Engine project
browser open, but if you don't, let's
just walk through it again. Go to your
Epic Games library. Go to the Epic Games
Launcher. Go to Unreal Engine Library
and then choose your installation and go
ahead and press launch. Once you've
launched Unreal Engine, it's going to
take you to the Unreal project browser.
The Unreal project browser is going to
be where you can access your various
different projects you have on your
computer. But most importantly, this is
going to be where you create new
projects. On the left hand side here,
you can see we have a variety of
different templates. And these different
templates are going to be for different
industries and they're going to give you
default content and plugins to help you
speed up the process of building your
project. In the case of video games, you
can see we've got templates such as
first person or third person, top down,
and so on. What I want us to do as we're
going to be building this platformer
with collectibles, I'm going to be using
the third person template as this is
going to allow us to have a character
and movement controls out of the box
with all of the scripting done for us.
All we have to then do is add our user
interface and our collectibles and all
of that on top of it. This is going to
save us a lot of time. So with your
third person template selected, we can
then go into selecting how this is going
to be formed. We have the choice between
blueprint and C++. Blueprint is Unreal
Engine visual scripting language and
then C++ is traditional programming. For
the purposes of this course, we are
going to be using blueprints. Then you
have the choice between target platform,
whether you want this to run on a
computer or a mobile device. I'm going
to leave this on desktop. Then you have
quality preset. Again, I'm going to be
leaving this on maximum. But then the
variant. This is really important. The
variants are going to come with your
different templates. For us, in this
case, we have combat, platforming, and
sidescroller. For this, what I'm going
to be doing is choosing the platforming
template. So, we've got that character,
we've got that movement, we've got the
controls all set up for us. Then when
you're ready, give your project a name.
I'm just going to give this the name,
first hour of Unreal. And then once I've
done that, I'm going to go ahead and
choose a location and press create.
Okay, now Unreal Engine has opened up
and I have the interface for the very
first time. What I want to do now is
just quickly run you through the various
different panels so you know where
everything is going to be. Let's hop
back into Unreal Engine. So if we go up
to window in the top lefthand corner,
the very first thing that I want you to
do is just make sure that you reset your
user interface. So you have exactly the
same layout as me. You can do this by
going to window load layout and then
we're going to be using the default
editor layout. Once we've done that, now
let's take a look at all of the various
different panels. The first panel that
we have is our viewport. Our viewport is
going to be our view into the 3D world
that we are building. We're not only
going to be building our world in there,
we're also going to be testing it.
Moving on from there, we have the
outliner in the top right hand corner.
The outliner is going to give you a list
of all of the different actors that you
have in your scene. That's going to be
everything from your player start
location to your lights or even the 3D
models that are actually in your world.
We also have the details panel. The
details panel is going to give you all
of the details about a selected actor.
For example, if I was to select this 3D
model in the middle by leftclicking on
it in my viewport, I can then see things
like the location, the materials, the
physics settings, everything for that
object. And also bear in mind that every
object or every actor rather is going to
have its own individual properties. For
example, the properties of a light is
going to be different to the properties
of a sound. But that is the details.
Again, we're going to be exploring this
as we get into the course. The next
panel that I want to take a look at is
our content drawer. The content drawer
can be accessed by pressing control
space on the keyboard to open and close
it or by pressing the content drawer
icon in the bottom leftand corner of the
screen.
Additionally, I find it easier to press
the dock in layout button to make sure
that my content drawer is always going
to be there. But in terms of what the
content drawer does, the content drawer
is essentially going to be your
location, your library of all of the
assets that you have in your project.
Those assets could be 3D models, they
could be sound effects, they could be um
blueprint scripts or anything like that.
And I would use this to essentially take
these assets and just drag and drop them
into the viewport. Again, we're going to
go over this as we get into the course.
Lastly, we have the main toolbar at the
top. This toolbar is going to have all
of our play controls. So, let's say we
want to play and test our platformer
that we're building. We can do that by
pressing the big green play button. Or
alternatively, you can press Alt and P
on your keyboard. And then we can click
in our viewport and we can use W and D
to move around, space to jump, and our
mouse to look around. And at any time
when we're ready to quit playing, we
just press escape on the keyboard. So
that's it for a very quick overview of
the Unreal Engine interface. Like I
said, we are going to be getting a lot
more familiar and a lot more comfortable
with all of this as we get into this
course and start building our project.
That being said, move on to the next
video to continue your learning journey.
And as always, stay awesome, keep
creating.
